signals.title: BLS Jan 2026: 130K Jobs, Healthcare Dominance Continues, Federal Workforce Collapse Deepens
key_data: 130K total nonfarm payrolls added in January 2026, unemployment at 4.3%
Healthcare added 81,900 jobs (63% of total): ambulatory +50,300, hospitals +18,300, nursing facilities +13,300
Healthcare monthly average was 33K in 2025 — Jan 2026 is 2.5x that pace
Federal government employment fell 34,000 — deferred resignation exits hitting payrolls
Federal employment down 327,000 (10.9%) since Oct 2024
Financial activities also lost jobs
signals.implication: Healthcare monoculture in job creation intensifies from v3-7 observations. At 63% of total job creation, this cycle confirms the pattern is not an anomaly but structural. Federal workforce drawdown of 327K (10.9%) in 16 months is unprecedented outside wartime demobilization — creating cascading effects on government services capacity, federal contracting pipeline, and D.C. regional economy. The combination of healthcare dominance + federal shrinkage means the labor market is structurally bifurcating.

signals.title: BLS Benchmark Revision: 2025 Job Growth Revised Down Sharply — Indeed Confirms 'Already Bad Year Worse'
key_data: 2025 annual revisions made already weak year materially worse
Follows 898K benchmark revision for March 2024 period
Cumulative 1.7M jobs overstated across 2024-2025
Indeed: 'Revisions to 2025 data made an already bad year worse'
Sustainable monthly job growth estimated at 20K-50K given immigration slowdown
signals.implication: Serial downward revisions (1.7M cumulative) mean the labor market has been weaker than reported for two years. This is not a one-time correction but a persistent measurement failure that distorted monetary policy, business hiring decisions, and consumer confidence. The forward implication is severe: if sustainable job growth is only 20K-50K/month, any normal economic softening tips into contraction. Policy decisions made on overstated data cannot be unmade.

signals.title: H-1B Wage-Weighted Lottery: Penn Wharton Projects 8.5% Avg Comp Increase, Level I Odds Collapse 90%
key_data: New DHS wage-weighted H-1B rule effective February 27, 2026
Level IV registrations entered 4x, Level III 3x, Level II 2x, Level I 1x
Level I selection probability drops from 27.1% to 2.5% — a 90% reduction
Average selected applicant compensation rises $9,554 (8.5%), from $112K to $122K
Wage effects on US-born workers negligible: -0.06% to +0.01% over 5 years
New $100,000 filing fee per petition also imposed
signals.implication: The wage-weighted lottery is the most significant structural change to US high-skilled immigration in decades. The 90% odds reduction for Level I workers effectively kills the body-shop staffing model (Infosys, TCS, Wipro-style mass applications). The $100K filing fee further prices out volume-based applicants. Penn Wharton's finding of negligible US wage impact undermines the 'protect American workers' framing — the real effect is reshaping WHICH foreign workers enter, not protecting domestic wages. This accelerates offshoring as Indian IT services pivot to serving US clients from India rather than placing workers onshore.

signals.title: Brookings: US Net Migration Turned Negative in 2025 — First Time in Half a Century
key_data: Net migration was between -295,000 and -10,000 in 2025 — first negative year in 50+ years
Down from +3 million in 2023 and +2 million in 2024
Negative net migration likely to continue in 2026
GDP impact: -0.2pp in 2025, -0.1 to -0.3pp in 2026
Breakeven monthly job growth drops to 50K or less; could turn negative in 2026
Direct labor force contraction implications for agriculture, construction, hospitality
signals.implication: A swing from +3M to near-zero or negative net migration in two years is a labor supply shock comparable to the pandemic. Unlike cyclical unemployment, this is a structural supply-side reduction that cannot be offset by monetary policy. The sectors most dependent on immigrant labor (agriculture, construction, hospitality, meatpacking) face acute workforce contraction. Combined with aging demographics and declining birth rates, this creates a triple squeeze on labor supply that raises the structural floor on wage inflation and limits GDP growth potential.

signals.title: Gen Z Hiring Inflows Down 45% vs 2019 — Average New Hire Age Now 42
key_data: Gen Z hiring inflows down 45% compared to 2019 levels
Hiring for workers 65+ up nearly 80% over same period
Average new hire age now 42 years old
Only 45% of Gen Z hold traditional full-time jobs
Gen Z expected to be 27% of workforce by end of 2026
OECD youth NEET rate: 1 in 4 young people globally
signals.implication: The labor market is aging from both ends: older workers staying longer (65+ hiring up 80%) while younger workers can't break in (Gen Z hiring down 45%). Average new hire age of 42 signals that employers are substituting experience for entry-level onboarding costs — a rational short-term response that creates a long-term skills pipeline crisis. When 55% of Gen Z are outside traditional full-time employment, it signals either a permanent shift to portfolio/gig work or a structural exclusion from the labor market. Either outcome fundamentally reshapes workforce composition by 2030.

signals.title: Enrollment Cliff Executing: Bloomberg Reports Dozens of Closures, 400 Schools May Vanish in Decade
key_data: 40+ schools announced closures since 2020, displacing students and faculty
Huron Consulting: ~400 schools could vanish in the coming decade
Fed Philadelphia model: up to 80 additional closures with 15% enrollment decline (2025-29)
High school graduates peak at 3.9M in 2025, followed by 15-year decline
13% decline in traditional-age incoming college students by 2041
Projected: 600K students displaced, $18B in endowment funds redistributed
Trinity Christian College (IL) shuttered Nov 2025 after 18% enrollment drop since 2019
signals.implication: The enrollment cliff is no longer a forecast — it is executing. The 15-year demographic lock (births from 2008-2019 determine 2026-2037 enrollment) is unfixable by any policy. This restructures the entire higher education ecosystem: small private colleges face extinction, mid-tier publics face consolidation, and only elite/flagship institutions maintain pricing power. The $18B endowment redistribution and 600K displaced students represent a capital and human capital reallocation event. College-dependent towns (particularly in Midwest/Northeast) face economic devastation.

signals.title: Nursing Shortage Rate at 8% Nationally, LPN Shortage 20% — Demand at 93rd Percentile
key_data: National nursing supply covers 91.94% of demand — 8.06% shortage rate
Licensed Practical Nurse shortage highest at 20%, RN shortage at 10%
Labor market demand-to-supply ratio at 93rd percentile (1.2 postings per nurse)
Median RN age was 52 in 2020; 20%+ planned to retire within 5 years
Thousands of qualified nursing applicants turned away annually due to faculty/capacity limits
194,500 average annual RN job openings projected through 2030
signals.implication: The nursing shortage is a structural bottleneck that constrains healthcare delivery capacity at the exact moment healthcare is the only significant job-creating sector. When demand sits at the 93rd percentile and the median age is 52, the pipeline gap is unfillable through traditional nursing education (capacity-constrained itself). This accelerates AI-assisted clinical decision support, telehealth expansion, and scope-of-practice reform. The 20% LPN shortage particularly impacts long-term care facilities and rural healthcare — precisely the settings most affected by aging demographics.

signals.title: Silver Tsunami: $10T in Small Business Assets Transitioning, <1/3 Have Succession Plans
key_data: 10M small companies (65-75% of all small firms) likely to sell as boomers exit
10,000 boomers retiring daily; all will be 65+ by 2030
Boomers own ~40% of all US small businesses
$10 trillion in private business assets changing hands
Less than 1/3 have succession plans
Only 30% of family businesses successfully transition to second generation
Nearly 60% of owners have no formal succession plan
signals.implication: The silver tsunami creates the largest ownership transfer in US economic history. With <1/3 having succession plans, the default outcome for millions of businesses is closure rather than transfer — destroying going-concern value, employment, and community economic bases. This creates a massive opportunity for PE roll-ups, employee ownership models (ESOPs), and platform acquisitions, but also a cliff event where accumulated business value is simply lost. The concentration of this event in 2026-2032 creates a buyer's market for business assets that inversely correlates with the capital availability to fund acquisitions.

signals.title: Office CMBS Delinquency Spikes to Record 12.3% — Exceeds Financial Crisis Peak by 1.6pp
key_data: Office CMBS delinquency rate spiked to 12.3% in January 2026
Exceeds 2010 Financial Crisis peak by 1.6 percentage points
Overall CMBS delinquency rate climbed to 7.47% (+17 bps from prior month)
Over $4B in newly delinquent loans in October 2025 alone
Moody's estimates office delinquency approaching 18% on their measure
Driven by high vacancy rates and near-term lease expiry concentrations
signals.implication: Office CMBS delinquency exceeding the Financial Crisis peak is a structural, not cyclical, event. Unlike 2008-2010, this is not driven by credit contagion but by permanent demand destruction — remote/hybrid work has structurally reduced office occupancy. The 12.3% rate with a trajectory toward 18% means losses are being realized, not merely marked-to-market. Banks with concentrated CRE exposure face capital ratio pressure, and regional banks are most vulnerable. The office-to-residential conversion thesis is partially valid but cannot absorb the scale of value destruction.

signals.title: AI VC Funding: Paradigm Shift from Software to Physical — $49.1B Defense Tech Record
key_data: ElevenLabs: $500M Series D at $11B valuation
Cerebras Systems: $1B Series H at $23B valuation
Positron AI: $230M Series B at $1B+ for energy-efficient AI inference
Goodfire: $150M Series B at $1.25B for AI interpretability
Accrual: $75M launch round for AI-native accounting automation
VC focus shifting from 'lightweight experimentation' to 'execution at industrial scale'
Capital flowing toward systems that 'move vehicles, manufacture goods, generate energy'
signals.implication: The VC conversation has fundamentally shifted from 'can AI work?' to 'can it scale in the physical world?' The mega-rounds (Cerebras $1B, ElevenLabs $500M) indicate capital concentration at the infrastructure and platform layers, not the application layer. The Accrual launch ($75M for AI accounting) signals that even back-office automation is now receiving deployment capital at scale. The shift toward physical-world AI (energy, manufacturing, vehicles) marks the transition from Phase 1 (digital-native AI) to Phase 2 (AI in atoms) of the capital deployment cycle.

signals.title: Defense Tech VC Doubles to Record $17.9B in 2025 — 1 in 12 VC Dollars Now Defense
key_data: Defense tech equity funding: $17.9B in 2025, up from $7.3B in 2024 (145% increase)
Total defense tech deals (including debt): $49.1B in 2025, up from $27.2B in 2024
Nearly 1 in 12 VC dollars now goes to defense tech sector
2026 challenge: proving startups can convert funding into production at scale
Manufacturing scale identified as 'next competitive battleground'
Ukraine demonstrated drone/autonomous system effectiveness driving investor confidence
signals.implication: Defense tech funding doubling in a single year signals a permanent capital reallocation, not a trend. When 1 in 12 VC dollars flows to defense, this is now a core allocation, not a niche bet. The 2026 pivot from R&D to manufacturing scale is the critical test: the gap between prototype and production-at-scale has historically killed defense startups. If the scaling bottleneck is cleared, it creates a parallel defense industrial base that competes with (and potentially displaces) legacy primes. The Ukraine validation loop — battlefield data informing product development — is a unique competitive advantage that traditional defense contractors lack.

signals.title: Fed Holds at 3.5-3.75%, Elevated Uncertainty — Markets Price Two Cuts, June Earliest
key_data: Fed funds rate held at 3.5-3.75% at January 2026 meeting
Statement: 'Uncertainty about the economic outlook remains elevated'
Vice Chair Bowman: downside risks to employment have not diminished
Housing sector activity 'remained weak'
CME FedWatch: two cuts expected in 2026, first in June at earliest
Political pressure from Trump administration to cut rates continues
Fed emphasized independence from political influence
signals.implication: The Fed is in a holding pattern with elevated uncertainty, caught between weakening employment data (downside risks haven't diminished per Bowman) and persistent inflation concerns. The 'uncertainty remains elevated' language is the key signal — it indicates the Fed itself cannot forecast with confidence, which constrains forward guidance and keeps capital allocation in limbo. Two cuts priced for 2026 means rate-sensitive sectors (housing, CRE, PE portfolio companies) face another 4-5 months of elevated cost of capital. The political pressure dynamic adds regime uncertainty to monetary policy.

signals.title: Corporate Bankruptcy Filings at 14-Year High — PE-Backed Defaults at 73% of Moody's Watchlist
key_data: 694 corporate bankruptcies in 2024 — highest since 2010
Upward trajectory expected through H1 2026
Companies with $100M+ assets filing up 44% by mid-2025
PE-backed companies: 73% of Moody's B3-negative-and-lower watchlist
Loan default rate ~4.3%, above pre-pandemic 2-3% average
Retail, dining, CRE, energy, healthcare, higher ed, non-bank finance most exposed
At least 24 distressed exchanges at PE-owned companies in 2024 (restructuring without formal filing)
signals.implication: PE-backed companies representing 73% of the highest-risk credit watchlist reveals the structural vulnerability of leveraged buyouts in a sustained higher-rate environment. The 4.3% default rate (vs 2-3% pre-pandemic) is not crisis-level but is chronic enough to erode portfolio returns and constrain PE fundraising. Distressed exchanges (24 in 2024) are the hidden iceberg — they avoid headline bankruptcy but impose losses on creditors and often result in zombie companies. The sector concentration (retail, CRE, healthcare, higher ed) maps directly to sectors already facing structural transformation pressures from other forces.

signals.title: IPO Pipeline Building: Anthropic, OpenAI, SpaceX Preparing — Potential Record-Breaking Year
key_data: Anthropic: retained Wilson Sonsini, informal bank talks, valued at $350B (Jan 2026 round at $10B+)
OpenAI: planning IPO for late 2026, fears Anthropic may list first
SpaceX: entered quiet period, projected $30B raise at $1.5T valuation
Canva: $42B valuation, $3.3B annualized revenue, strong IPO candidate
Databricks, Plaid, Cohere also closely watched
Market conditions described as 'strongest since 2021'
Proceeds could quadruple vs 2025
signals.implication: If Anthropic ($350B), OpenAI, and SpaceX ($1.5T) all go public in 2026, it would be the largest combined IPO year in market history and would redefine public market composition. These are not normal IPOs — they are economy-defining platforms. Anthropic and OpenAI going public creates the first pure-play AI stocks at scale, giving retail investors direct AI exposure and creating new index constituents that could draw passive fund flows. The 'quadrupling of proceeds' signals capital market appetite exists, but also that private markets are reaching the limits of their capacity to value these companies.

signals.title: ManpowerGroup: AI Usage Up 13% But Confidence Down 18% — 'Job Hugging' Emerges as Coping Mechanism
key_data: Regular AI usage jumped 13% to 45% of workers globally
Confidence in technology plummeted 18% — first decline in 3 years
43% of workers fear automation may replace their job within 2 years
64% of workers 'job hugging' — staying with current employer for stability
Baby Boomers: 35% drop in tech confidence; Gen X: 25% drop
56% of workforce received no recent training; 57% no access to mentorship
Overall Global Talent Barometer score: 67%
India leads globally at 77% sentiment; Japan lowest at 48%
signals.implication: The ManpowerGroup data reveals the psychology paradox at the heart of AI transformation: usage is accelerating but trust is collapsing. The 'job hugging' phenomenon (64% staying put out of fear) is the inverse of the Great Resignation — workers are now frozen rather than mobile. This has profound implications: labor market fluidity drops, reducing allocative efficiency; workers accept suboptimal conditions rather than risk job transitions; and innovation adoption at the firm level is constrained by workforce resistance. The 56% receiving no training is the mechanism — organizations are deploying AI tools without investing in human readiness, creating the exact fear response the tools are designed to reduce.

signals.title: Enterprise AI: 78% Deploy but Only 23% Measure ROI — The 'AI Accountability Crisis'
signals.source: Deloitte State of AI in Enterprise 2026 / ETR Research / CIO.com (Feb 2026)
key_data: 78% of enterprises use AI in at least one business function
Only 23% actively measure their return on investment
Only 1/3 have seen tangible revenue increase or cost reduction from AI deployments
74% of executives claim ROI within first year (likely self-reported/aspirational)
AI agents: 39% of executives deployed 10+ agents across enterprise
Applications embedding agent capabilities jumped from <5% (2025) to 40% (2026)
66% report productivity/efficiency gains — but measuring methodology varies widely
Average company invested $1.9M in GenAI projects
signals.implication: The gap between deployment rate (78%) and measurement rate (23%) is the defining psychology signal of early 2026. Enterprises are spending billions on AI without knowing whether it works — this is faith-based technology adoption, not evidence-based. The conflict between '74% claim ROI' and 'only 1/3 see tangible benefits' suggests executive-level cognitive dissonance: leaders have committed publicly and cannot admit failure. The agentic AI jump (5% to 40% in one year) indicates a second wave of deployment is occurring before the first wave's results are verified. This is classic Gartner pre-trough behavior and sets up a correction event.

signals.title: GenAI Enters Gartner Trough of Disillusionment — 2-5 Year Recovery Timeline
signals.source: Gartner Hype Cycle for AI / CIO.com (Feb 2026)
key_data: GenAI officially entering Trough of Disillusionment per Gartner
Average company invested $1.9M in GenAI (2024) with <30% CEO satisfaction
Hallucinations and inconsistent results cited as major lowered-expectation drivers
Gartner estimates 2-5 years to reach Plateau of Productivity
Focus shifting from GenAI hype to 'foundational innovations' built responsibly
Organization-wide AI scaling replacing pilot/POC era
signals.implication: Gartner's formal placement of GenAI in the Trough is a timing signal, not a death sentence. Historical Gartner patterns show the Trough is where real enterprise value emerges — companies that deploy during the Trough with disciplined ROI measurement capture disproportionate competitive advantage. The 2-5 year timeline (2028-2031) aligns with the economy map's 5-year projection window. CEO dissatisfaction at <30% will trigger a shift from 'buy everything AI' to 'prove it works' purchasing behavior, benefiting enterprise-grade solutions with measurable outcomes over experimental tools. This is the natural correction to the accountability crisis identified in S16.

signals.title: State AI Regulation Accelerates: 1,200 Bills in 2025, Colorado/Texas Laws Now in Force
signals.source: IAPP / Transparency Coalition AI Legislative Update (Feb 6, 2026)
key_data: 1,200 AI-related bills introduced across all 50 states in 2025
Colorado AI Act effective 2026: algorithmic discrimination protections, impact assessments required
Texas Responsible AI Governance Act 2026: high-impact system requirements, sandbox program
California: multiple AI transparency and employment laws enacted
Michigan: bill to allow civil action for chatbot harms to minors
38 states passed AI legislation in 2025
Trump EO directs Commerce to evaluate state AI laws for federal preemption
AI Litigation Task Force established to challenge state regulations
signals.implication: The state-level regulatory explosion (1,200 bills, 38 states passing legislation) is creating a patchwork compliance environment that particularly burdens mid-market enterprises lacking the legal resources of Big Tech. Colorado and Texas laws going into force in 2026 create the first binding obligations for high-risk AI systems. The federal preemption dynamic (Trump EO vs. state laws) creates regulatory uncertainty that is itself a psychological barrier to deployment. Companies face a choice between waiting for regulatory clarity (losing competitive advantage) or deploying now (risking compliance costs). This state/federal tension will define the US AI governance landscape for 2-3 years.

signals.title: Deepfake Trust Erosion Accelerates: $12.5B in Financial Fraud, Courts Sanctioning Deepfake Evidence
signals.source: NBC News / Cogent / Keepnet Labs / Cyble (Feb 2026)
key_data: US financial fraud losses reached $12.5B in 2025, AI-assisted attacks a growing share
Multi-million dollar deepfake-enabled losses already documented in early 2026
California judge issued terminating sanction for deepfake video evidence (Mendones v. Cushman & Wakefield)
People equally likely to identify real content as fake and fake content as real
Accuracy worsens significantly for politically-toned content
Deepfakes spreading in first week of 2026 around major news events
Enterprise-grade deepfake defense now demanded by corporations
signals.implication: Deepfake trust erosion is now affecting three critical domains simultaneously: financial systems ($12.5B fraud), legal proceedings (evidence sanctioning), and public discourse (political deepfakes). The finding that people are equally likely to call real things fake as fake things real is the terminal state of epistemic collapse — it means deepfakes damage trust in ALL content, not just fake content. This has second-order effects on every institution that depends on evidence, testimony, or verified communication: courts, media, financial markets, elections. The enterprise defense market is emerging but is fundamentally a red-queen race.

signals.title: Higher Education AI Policy Hardens: Ohio Mandates AI Policy by July 2026, $169M Federal Grants
signals.source: Inside Higher Ed / Fordham Institute / US Dept of Education (Feb 2026)
key_data: US Dept of Education: $169M FIPSE grants for responsible AI in teaching/learning
Ohio mandates formal AI policy for all public schools by July 1, 2026
AI literacy expected to be embedded across every degree program by end of 2026
Shift from 'panic and pilot' (2023-2025) to 'habits harden' (2026)
AI repositioned as institutional strategy tool, not experimental add-on
K-12 AI policies setting 'defaults for how a generation learns, works, and thinks with AI'
signals.implication: Education AI policy is transitioning from experimental to mandatory — Ohio's mandate is the template for other states. The $169M federal investment and universal AI literacy requirements signal that the education system is accepting AI as permanent infrastructure rather than a trend to resist or a tool to ban. The 'habits harden' framing is critical: the policies schools adopt NOW will shape how an entire generation relates to AI in the workforce. If education institutions embed AI as a co-learning tool, the psychological acceptance curve for the broader workforce accelerates. If they treat it as a compliance burden, they reproduce the fear/resistance patterns seen in the ManpowerGroup data.

signals.title: Fortune/McKinsey: AI Efficiency Programs Look Like Tomorrow's Job Cuts — Leader Trust is the Bottleneck
key_data: Workers interpret AI 'efficiency programs' as precursors to layoffs
Fear of AI-driven job displacement nearly doubled in 2025 vs prior year
More than 1 in 4 employees distrust employer's ability to deploy AI fairly
63% report fatigue driven by stress and heavy workloads
McKinsey: 'AI won't decide the future — leaders will'
Leadership trust identified as the critical bottleneck for AI transformation
Workers need 'transparency, agency, and clear investment in their growth'
signals.implication: The Fortune/McKinsey framing crystallizes the psychology barrier: workers correctly identify that 'efficiency' is corporate language for 'fewer people needed.' When AI fear doubles in one year and >25% distrust employer AI deployment, the transformation timeline extends regardless of the technology's capability. This is the fear friction gap in action — economic readiness (the technology works) vastly outpaces psychological readiness (workers don't trust the intent). McKinsey's prescription ('leaders will decide') shifts accountability from technology to management, which is correct but also reveals that most management teams lack the trust capital to execute.

signals.title: Mercer: Workers 'Job Hugging' — AI and Economic Anxiety Freezing Labor Mobility
key_data: Amid economic and AI anxieties, US employees are choosing to stay put
Complete reversal from Great Resignation dynamics
Workers accepting suboptimal conditions over perceived risk of job change
Voluntary quit rates declining as fear of automation rises
Employers retain workers at lower cost but face frozen innovation/reallocation
Burnout increasing among 'job huggers' who stay despite dissatisfaction
signals.implication: Job hugging is the behavioral manifestation of the fear friction gap at the individual level. When workers freeze rather than move, the labor market loses its primary mechanism for price discovery and talent reallocation. The economic effects are contradictory: employers retain experienced workers at lower turnover cost (positive for margins) but lose the creative destruction that job switching enables (negative for innovation and sectoral rebalancing). This is Polanyi's 'double movement' — society protecting itself from transformation by reducing participation in the transforming system. The burnout accumulation among job huggers creates a delayed-release pressure: when the dam breaks, it will look like a sudden mass resignation, but the causes will have been building for years.

sources_consulted: Brookings Institution — Macroeconomic implications of immigration flows (Jan 2026)
Deloitte State of AI in Enterprise 2026
Gartner Hype Cycle for AI / CIO.com
IAPP / Transparency Coalition AI Legislative Update (Feb 6, 2026)
NBC News / Cogent / Keepnet Labs / Cyble (Feb 2026)
Inside Higher Ed / Fordham / US Dept of Education
key_cross_force_patterns: Healthcare Monoculture + Nursing Shortage: Healthcare creates 63% of jobs but faces 8-20% nursing shortage — the growth sector cannot fill its own positions (F2 x F2)
BLS Revisions + Fed Uncertainty: 1.7M cumulative overstatement undermines the data foundation for monetary policy decisions; Fed itself citing 'elevated uncertainty' (F2 x F4)
AI Investment Surge + Accountability Crisis: $49B in defense tech, $billions in AI VC, but only 23% of enterprises measure AI ROI — capital is flowing faster than evidence (F4 x F5)

Job Hugging + Enrollment Cliff: Workers frozen by AI fear while higher education (the traditional upskilling pathway) faces demographic collapse — the retraining infrastructure is failing at the moment of peak need (F5 x F2)
GenAI Trough + State Regulation: Gartner Trough timing coincides with state regulatory activation — enterprises face simultaneous disillusionment and compliance burden (F5 x F5)

Negative Net Migration + Construction/Agriculture Labor: Labor supply shock from immigration reversal hits physical economy sectors hardest, precisely where AI automation is least deployable (F2 x F4)

Silver Tsunami + PE Distress: $10T in small business assets hitting market while PE-backed companies show elevated default risk — capital for acquisitions may be constrained when supply peaks (F2 x F4)

velocity_assessment.F2_demographics: Accelerating. Three simultaneous demographic shocks executing: negative net migration (new), enrollment cliff (confirmed), silver tsunami (building). The BLS revision confirms the labor market was weaker than believed, and the H-1B overhaul adds a structural change to high-skilled immigration within 15 days.
velocity_assessment.F4_capital: Bifurcating. AI/defense tech capital is accelerating exponentially (defense VC doubling YoY) while CRE/office is in structural crisis (12.3% CMBS delinquency exceeds GFC). Fed paralysis and PE distress add drag. Capital is being reallocated violently from old economy to new economy, with the middle being hollowed out.
velocity_assessment.F5_psychology: Deepening. The usage-confidence gap (usage +13%, confidence -18%) is the headline metric. GenAI entering the Gartner Trough, state regulation activating, deepfake trust erosion, and worker 'job hugging' all point to a psychology force that is now acting as a material brake on technological adoption timelines. The fear friction gap is widening, not closing.
